headline: Gov. Walz urges Noem to review Minnesota ICE arrests after reports of detained U.S. citizens
summary: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz has asked Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem to review recent ICE arrests after reports that at least two U.S. citizens were detained this week, including one man who says officers ignored his citizenship claims and a woman arrested for confronting agents. Walz demanded that agents who acted unlawfully be placed on administrative leave and called for clarification on legal standards for citizens observing law enforcement and clearer guidance on respecting civil rights. The governor also urged Noem to reassess the Trump administration’s broader "surge" enforcement strategy that has increased federal agent presence in Minnesota over the past two weeks. DHS has identified 19 people arrested who are allegedly in the U.S. illegally with criminal records, while Walz warned that detaining citizens under questionable circumstances damages public trust and civil liberties. Walz, who is seeking reelection to a third term, emphasized that state safety depends on justice, fairness, and respect for civil liberties.

headline: Newly released data shows sharp decline of inmates at New Mexico ICE facility
summary: Since Torrance County's ICE contract expired October 31, detainee numbers at the Estancia jail dropped from 700 to roughly 250, prompting county officials to warn of potential economic losses if the facility closes and immigrant advocates to raise alarms about substandard care without legal oversight; U.S. Sen. Martin Heinrich has pressed ICE to explain its legal authority for continued detention, citing standard procedures that require detainee removal absent a contract, while the decline contrasts with rising populations at New Mexico's other ICE facilities amid the Trump administration's mass deportation push.

headline: Michigan House Republicans reject over $600 million in work project spending
summary: The Michigan House Appropriations Committee voted along party lines to reject $645 million in previously approved work project spending, which will be redirected to the state's general fund. Democrats criticized the lack of debate, fiscal agency testimony, and transparency, noting the cuts affect community colleges, public safety, and survivor justice programs.

headline: Hall, Bollin defend vote halting $645M in spending as Democrats decry ‘untransparent’ process
summary: The Michigan House Appropriations Committee voted along party lines to disapprove $645 million in work project spending, redirecting those funds to the state's general fund under the Management and Budget Act. Republican leaders framed the move as eliminating waste and pork, while Democrats criticized the lack of transparency and debate before the vote. The cuts affected projects including climate infrastructure, sexual assault kits, community colleges, and public safety initiatives. Disapproved projects will now be reviewed under the Hall Ethics, Accountability and Transparency plan. This rare use of the committee's unilateral rejection authority marks a significant budgetary and political escalation.

headline: Vermont Gov. Phil Scott backs calls for embattled Addison County prosecutor Eva Vekos to resign
summary: No protests or civil unrest are reported in the article, but the escalating bipartisan political pressure and Progressive Party impeachment threat against Addison County State's Attorney Eva Vekos regarding sexual assault case handling could catalyze future demonstrations concerning prosecutorial accountability and victims' rights.

headline: Send us news tips on I.C.E. in Mississippi
summary: Federal "Operation Catahoula Crunch" has deployed hundreds of border agents to Mississippi and New Orleans for a two-month period targeting approximately 5,000 arrests. While officials claim to focus on individuals with criminal backgrounds, national data indicates over 70% of immigration detainees have no criminal records. Law enforcement presence has been reported across Mississippi, including the Jackson metro area. Similar operations in other cities have seen sustained enforcement activity. The deployment represents a significant federal immigration enforcement action in the state with potential policy implications for local communities.

headline: Migrants held at Fort Bliss suffering physical abuse, unsafe conditions, human rights groups claim
summary: The East Montana Detention Facility at Fort Bliss in El Paso is under construction with capacity for 5,000 migrants, representing significant expansion of federal immigration detention infrastructure. This military base location demonstrates government policy to leverage defense installations for immigration enforcement. The facility reflects federal prioritization of detention capacity as a core enforcement strategy. Its construction indicates ongoing policy commitment to large-scale migrant detention in Texas. This development will substantially increase the state's capacity to detain migrants.

headline: Nikki Fried: ‘The pendulum is swinging’ towards Democrats’ after victory in Miami election
summary: Florida Democratic Party Chair Nikki Fried interprets recent election results—including a 20-point swing toward Democrats in Senate District 11 and an 18-point victory in Miami's mayoral race—as indicators of shifting public opinion against Republican governance, prompting the DCCC to target four GOP congressional districts, while Republican officials counter that their 1.4 million voter registration advantage demonstrates enduring support, all without citing actual polling data.

headline: New polling shows Mills ahead of Platner in an overall tight race for Senate
summary: Portland-based Pan Atlantic Research surveyed 820 likely Maine voters (Nov. 29-Dec. 7) and found Gov. Janet Mills leading Graham Platner 47%-37% in the Democratic Senate primary, though 14% remain undecided. Mills dominates in Maine's conservative 2nd District and among voters 55+, while Platner leads in the 1st District and holds a 40+ point advantage with voters aged 18-34. Both Democratic candidates are statistically tied with Republican Sen. Susan Collins in hypothetical general election matchups (Mills 43%-43%; Platner 43%-42%). Mills posts a net -8 favorability rating, better than Collins' -17 and Trump's -19. The poll identifies inflation/cost of living as the top concern for 68% of Mainers, while 48% say the state is on the wrong track and 46% report being financially worse off than a year ago.

headline: PSC hearings disrupted by protestors after surprise agreement with Georgia Power
summary: Several demonstrators disrupted a Georgia Public Service Commission meeting with chants opposing a surprise agreement to approve Georgia Power's full $16 billion energy expansion request, primarily for data centers; police escorted them out without making arrests, and some were permitted to return, while commission Chair Jason Shaw noted advocacy lawyers had time to review the deal before afternoon hearings.
